what: Introduction: Why R2R^2 is Not Unique
title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: many statistical software packages, coefficient determination (R2R^2) presented singular, definitive value. However, Tarald O. Kvalseth pointed seminal 1985 paper, “Cautionary Note R2R^2”, multiple ways define calculate metric. definitions converge standard linear regression intercept, can diverge dramatically contexts, models without intercept power regression models. kvr2 package designed educational tool explore mathematical sensitivity.

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: Kvalseth (1985) classified eight existing formulas proposed one robust alternative. core definitions used package:

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: R12R^2_1: common form, measuring proportion variance explained. Kvalseth strongly recommends consistency. R12=1−∑(y−ŷ)2∑(y−y‾)2R_1^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(y - \hat{y})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2} R22R^2_2: Often used contexts, can exceed 1.0 -intercept models. R22=∑(ŷ−y‾)2∑(y−y‾)2R_2^2 = \frac{\sum(\hat{y} - \bar{y})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2} R62R^2_6: square Pearson’s correlation coefficient observed predicted values. R62=(∑(y−y‾)(ŷ−ŷ‾))2∑(y−y‾)2∑(ŷ−ŷ‾)2R_6^2 = \frac{\left( \sum(y - \bar{y})(\hat{y} - \bar{\hat{y}}) \right)^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2 \sum(\hat{y} - \bar{\hat{y}})^2}

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: R72R^2_7: Specifically designed models passing origin. R72=1−∑(y−ŷ)2∑y2R_7^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(y - \hat{y})^2}{\sum y^2}

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: R92R^2_9: Proposed Kvalseth resist influence outliers using medians (MM). R92=1−(M{|yi−ŷ|}M{|yi−y‾|})2R_9^2 = 1 - \left( \frac{M\{|y_i - \hat{y}_i|\}}{M\{|y_i - \bar{y}|\}} \right)^2

what: Case Study: The Danger of No-Intercept Models
title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: Let’s use example data Kvalseth (1985) see values diverge remove intercept.
code: library(kvr2) df1 <- data.frame(x = 1:6, y = c(15, 37, 52, 59, 83, 92))  # Model without an intercept model_no_int <- lm(y ~ x - 1, data = df1)  # Calculate all 9 types results <- r2(model_no_int) results #> R2_1 :  0.9777  #> R2_2 :  1.0836  #> R2_3 :  1.0830  #> R2_4 :  0.9783  #> R2_5 :  0.9808  #> R2_6 :  0.9808  #> R2_7 :  0.9961  #> R2_8 :  0.9961  #> R2_9 :  0.9717

previous_headings: Case Study: The Danger of No-Intercept Models
title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: Notice R22R^2_2 R32R^2_3 greater 1.0. happens , without intercept, standard sum squares relationship (SStot=SSreg+SSresSS_{tot} = SS_{reg} + SS_{res}) longer holds. researcher blindly reports R22R^2_2, result mathematically nonsensical. Kvalseth argues R12R^2_1 generally preferable remains bounded 1.0 maintains clear interpretation “error reduction.”

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: power regression models (typically fitted via log-log transformation), definition “mean” “residuals” becomes ambiguous. R2R^2 refer transformed space original space? case, kvr2 automatically detects transformation (type = "auto") helps evaluate reported fit consistent research goals.

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity
text: kvr2 package demonstrates R2R^2 “plug--play” statistic. comparing nine definitions, users can: Identify model fit - -represented specific formula. Understand Kvalseth recommended R12R^2_1 consistency R92R^2_9 robustness. critical R2R^2 values reported scientific literature.

title: The Pitfalls of R-squared: Understanding Mathematical Sensitivity

what: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: kvr2 package provides functions calculate nine types coefficients determination (R2R^2) classified Kvalseth (1985).

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: coefficient determination, R2R^2, one common metrics assessing model fit. However, mathematical definition unique. various formulas yield identical results standard linear regression intercept, can diverge significantly—sometimes producing negative values values exceeding 1—applied : Models without intercept (-intercept models) Power regression models fits via transformations (e.g., log-log models)

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: package specifically designed models can represented lm objects R. includes: Standard Linear Models (intercept) -intercept Models (e.g., lm(y ~ x - 1)) Power Regression Models (fitted via log-transformation, lm(log(y) ~ log(x))) Note: package support general non-linear least squares (nls) complex non-linear modeling frameworks. focuses mathematical sensitivity R2R^2 within context linear estimation common transformations.

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: primary goal package provide definitive “best” R2R^2 every scenario, serve educational resource. providing comprehensive list definitions, helps users understand mathematical sensitivity goodness--fit indices. package, users can: Observe Variability: See firsthand choice algebraic formula can lead different interpretations model. Identify Pitfalls: Recognize certain definitions inappropriate specific model types (e.g., lack intercept affects sum squares). Analyze Recommendations: Explore Kvalseth’s arguments R12R^2_1 (R92R^2_9 robust cases) often preferred consistency comparability.

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: package calculates nine indices based Kvalseth (1985): R12R^2_1 R82R^2_8: classification existing historical formulas used statistical literature software. R92R^2_9: robust version coefficient determination based median absolute deviations, proposed original paper.

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: can install development version kvr2 like :

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: kvr2 provides simple way observe different R2R^2 definitions behave across various model specifications.

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: standard linear models intercept, R2R^2 definitions yield identical results. However, can diverge significantly models without intercept power regression models. Observation: Case B, notice R22R^2_2 R32R^2_3 exceed 1.0. demonstrates choosing correct definition critical models without intercept.
code: library(kvr2)  # Dataset from Kvalseth (1985) df1 <- data.frame(x = 1:6, y = c(15, 37, 52, 59, 83, 92))  # Case A: Linear regression with intercept (Values are consistent) model_int <- lm(y ~ x, data = df1) r2(model_int) #> R2_1 :  0.9808  #> R2_2 :  0.9808  #> R2_3 :  0.9808  #> R2_4 :  0.9808  #> R2_5 :  0.9808  #> R2_6 :  0.9808  #> R2_7 :  0.9966  #> R2_8 :  0.9966  #> R2_9 :  0.9778  # Case B: Linear regression without intercept (Values diverge) model_no_int <- lm(y ~ x - 1, data = df1) results <- r2(model_no_int) results #> R2_1 :  0.9777  #> R2_2 :  1.0836  #> R2_3 :  1.0830  #> R2_4 :  0.9783  #> R2_5 :  0.9808  #> R2_6 :  0.9808  #> R2_7 :  0.9961  #> R2_8 :  0.9961  #> R2_9 :  0.9717

title: Calculate and Compare Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination
text: r2() function returns list object. output formatted readability, can easily access individual values analysis reporting.
code: # Accessing specific R2 values from the result object results$r2_1 #>      r2_1  #> 0.9776853  results$r2_9 #>      r2_9  #> 0.9717156  # You can also use it in your custom functions or data frames my_val <- results$r2_1

what: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: Calculates goodness--fit metrics based Kvalseth (1985), including Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Squared Error (MSE). function provides unified output comparing different model specifications.

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
code: comp_fit(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  RMSE(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  MAE(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  MSE(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: model linear model power regression model lm. type Character string. Selects model type: "linear", "power", "auto" (default). "auto", function detects dependent variable log-transformed.

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: object class comp_kvr2, list containing calculated RMSE, MAE, MSE values.

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: metrics calculated according formulas Kvalseth (1985): RMSE: Root Mean Squared Residual Error $$RMSE = \sqrt{\frac{\sum (y - \hat{y})^2}{n}}$$ MAE: Mean Absolute Residual Error $$MAE = \frac{\sum |y - \hat{y}|}{n}$$ MSE: Mean Squared Residual Error (Adjusted degrees freedom) $$MSE = \frac{\sum (y - \hat{y})^2}{n - p}$$ \(n\) sample size \(p\) number model parameters (including intercept). Note MSE: many modern contexts, "MSE" refers mean squared error without degree--freedom adjustment (denominator \(n\)). However, function follows Kvalseth's definition, uses \(n - p\) denominator.

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: power regression model must based logarithmic transformation. auto-selection linear regression power regression models determined whether dependent variable's name contains “log”. name “log” intentionally used linear regression model, selection made correctly.

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
text: Tarald O. Kvalseth (1985) Cautionary Note R 2 , American Statistician, 39:4, 279-285, doi: 10.1080/00031305.1985.10479448

title: Calculate Comparative Fit Measures for Regression Models — comp_fit
code: # example data set 1. Kvålseth (1985). df1 <- data.frame(x = c(1:6),                  y = c(15,37,52,59,83,92)) model_intercept <- lm(y ~ x, df1) model_without <- lm(y ~ x - 1, df1) model_power <- lm(log(y) ~ log(x), df1) comp_fit(model_intercept) #> RMES :  3.6165  #> MAE :  3.5238  #> MSE :  19.6190  comp_fit(model_without) #> RMES :  3.9008  #> MAE :  3.6520  #> MSE :  18.2593  comp_fit(model_power) #> RMES :  3.8982  #> MAE :  3.6334  #> MSE :  22.7938

title: Print Methods for r2 and comp_fit calculation Objects — print.r2_kvr2

what: Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
title: Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
text: Calculate adjusted coefficient determination entering regression model coefficient determination. See details.

title: Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
text: model linear model power regression model lm. r2 numeric. Coefficient determination.

title: Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
text: adjustment factor \(\) calculated using following formula. $$= (n - 1) / (n - k - 1)$$ \(n\) sample size, \(k\) number parameters regression model. \(R^2_a\) (\(R^2 adjusted\)) calculated using following formula. $$R^2_a = 1 - (1 - R^2)$$ function performs freedom--degrees adjustment coefficients based formula. However, Kvalseth (1985) recommends applying freedom--degrees adjustment \(R^2_1\) \(R^2_9\), based principle consistency coefficients. Furthermore, basis applying type adjustment \(R^2_6\) (square correlation coefficient) \(R^2_7\) \(R^2_8\), depend specific model forms. details coefficient determination, refer r2.

title: Calculate the adjusted determination coefficient — r2_adjusted
text: Tarald O. Kvalseth (1985) Cautionary Note R 2 , American Statistician, 39:4, 279-285, doi:10.1080/00031305.1985.10479448

what: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: Calculates nine types coefficients determination (\(R^2\)) based classification Kvalseth (1985). function designed demonstrate \(R^2\) values can vary depending mathematical definition, particularly models without intercept power regression models

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
code: r2(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"), adjusted = FALSE)  r2_1(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_2(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_3(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_4(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_5(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_6(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_7(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_8(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))  r2_9(model, type = c("auto", "liner", "power"))

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: model linear model power regression model lm. type Character string. Selects model type: "linear", "power", "auto" (default). "auto", function detects dependent variable log-transformed. adjusted Logical. TRUE, calculates adjusted coefficient determination formula.

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: object class r2_kvr2, list containing calculated values \(R^2\) formula.

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: nine coefficient equations \(R^2_1\) \(R^2_9\) based Kvalseth (1985) follows: \(R^2_1\): Proportion total variance explained. $$R_1^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(y - \hat{y})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2}$$ \(R^2_2\): Based variation predicted values. $$R^2_2 = \frac{\sum(\hat{y} - \bar{y})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2}$$ \(R^2_3\): Ratio variation using mean predicted values. $$R_3^2 = \frac{\sum(\hat{y} - \bar{\hat{y}})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2}$$ \(R^2_4\): Incorporates mean residual. $$R_4^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(e - \bar{e})^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2}, \quad e = y - \hat{y}$$ \(R^2_5\): square multiple correlation coefficient dependent variable independent variable (comprehensive indicator linearized models). $$R_5^2 = \text{squared multiple correlation coefficient regressand regressors}$$ \(R^2_6\): Square Pearson's correlation coefficient observed \(y\) predicted \(\hat{y}\). $$R_6^2 = \frac{\left( \sum(y - \bar{y})(\hat{y} - \bar{\hat{y}}) \right)^2}{\sum(y - \bar{y})^2 \sum(\hat{y} - \bar{\hat{y}})^2}$$ \(R^2_7\): Recommended models without intercept. $$R_7^2 = 1 - \frac{\sum(y - \hat{y})^2}{\sum y^2}$$ \(R^2_8\): Alternative form models without intercept. $$R_8^2 = \frac{\sum \hat{y}^2}{\sum y^2}$$ \(R^2_9\): Robust version using medians resist outliers. $$R_9^2 = 1 - \left( \frac{M\{|y_i - \hat{y}_i|\}}{M\{|y_i - \bar{y}|\}} \right)^2$$ \(M\) represents median sample. degree freedom adjustment adjusted = TRUE, refer r2_adjusted.

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: power regression model must based logarithmic transformation. auto-selection linear regression power regression models determined whether dependent variable's name contains “log”. name “log” intentionally used linear regression model, selection made correctly.

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
text: Tarald O. Kvalseth (1985) Cautionary Note R 2 , American Statistician, 39:4, 279-285, doi:10.1080/00031305.1985.10479448  Box, George E. P., Hunter, William G., Hunter, J. Stuart. (1978) Statistics experimenters: introduction design, data analysis, model building. New York, United States, J. Wiley, p. 462-473, ISBN:9780471093152.

title: Calculate Multiple Definitions of Coefficient of Determination (R-squared) — r2
code: # Example data set 1. Kvalseth (1985). df1 <- data.frame(x = c(1:6),                  y = c(15,37,52,59,83,92)) # Linear regression model with intercept model_intercept1 <- lm(y ~ x, df1) # Linear regression model without intercept model_without1 <- lm(y ~ x - 1, df1) # Power regression model model_power1 <- lm(log(y) ~ log(x), df1) r2(model_intercept1) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df1' not found r2(model_without1) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df1' not found r2(model_power1) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df1' not found # Example data set 2. Kvalseth (1985). df2 <- data.frame(x = 6:13,                   y = c(3882, 1266, 733, 450, 410, 305, 185, 112)) power_model2 <- lm(log((y/7343)) ~ log(x), data = df2) r2(power_model2) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df2' not found # Example of a Multiple Regression Analysis Model. # The data for two independent variables given by Box et al. (1978, p. 462) # as used in Kvalseth (1985). df3 <- data.frame(x1 = c(0.34, 0.34, 0.58, 1.26, 1.26, 1.82),                   x2 = c(0.73, 0.73, 0.69, 0.97, 0.97, 0.46),                   y = c(5.75, 4.79, 5.44, 9.09, 8.59, 5.09)) # Multiple regression analysis model with intercept model_intercept3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2, df3) # Multiple regression analysis model without intercept model_without3 <- lm(y ~ x1 + x2 - 1, df3) # Multiple power regression analysis model model_power3 <- lm(log(y) ~ log(x1) + log(x2), df3) r2(model_intercept3) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df3' not found r2(model_without3) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df3' not found r2(model_power3) #> Error in eval(mf, parent.frame()): object 'df3' not found
